Posts.Content: Hi Aspen, So sorry you find yourself here! I just wanted to reassure you though. I had FEC-T, starting Feb 6th and finishing may 26th this year. While I can't pretend it was pleasant, it's absolutely manageable. Like you, I had chemo before any surgery and honestly I felt pretty well after the first dose, especially as you get steroids which made me buzz with energy!  So, it will get tougher and you will need to be kind to yourself but don't write Christmas off, you should be able to enjoy it from a physical point of view though your emotions will be all over the place if you're anything like me. Much love.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, chemo about to start

Posts.Content: So thrilled about your path' report. Good luck with the radio.  Much love Batfink aka Carolyn
Posts.Title: Post surgery path report

Posts.Content: I am about to go for diep and wondered how you were all doing 4 years on? Xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: I'm on EC-T chemo and have had increased palpitations since the start. I have had them for 2 years pre-diagnosis though and after 6 months of investigations was told they are probably caused by peri-menopause. So maybe it's just to do with hormone levels? I haven't thought to mention them at hospital as I've had them so often before. You've made me think though....I should let them know! Xxx
Posts.Title: Palpitations with an abnormal ecg 3 weeks after TCHP cycle 3.. help...

Posts.Content: Hi I was told chemo first but when I asked why they got all defensive and said I could do surgery first if I preferred!  I asked what difference it made and was told that statistics show the order doesn't affect recurrence or survival rates. I wanted an immediate reconstruction (which I've now had) and that works best if you do chemo first so I stuck with plan A. Basically, I'll do whatever they tell me to get rid of it! Xxx
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: 'witch' Knowing you're not alone IS help! Thanks. Xxx
Posts.Title: New side effect, trouble swallowing.

Posts.Content: Hi all. Ive had my third EC today about 5 hours ago.  Just eaten some tea and half way through suddenly couldn't swallow. It wasnt painful it was just like my throat had forgotten how to work. I suspect peristalsis is affected by chemo as it would explain the horrendous constipation,  but just wondered if anyone else had experience this? Caz
Posts.Title: New side effect, trouble swallowing.

Posts.Content: Just wondered if anyone has had similar. I had a ct scan during radiotherapy in October as I was breathless. It showed an enlarged thymus gland. I was rescanned 2 weeks ago in the hope it had reduced (it shouldn't be visible in an adult). It is still the same size. The letter says it will be discussed at my next appointment on 23rd Feb. Is that good, that they'e willing to leave it a month or could it be a secondary? I can feel total panic mode coming on again.
Posts.Title: Enlarged thymus gland.

Posts.Content: So pleased to hear this Optimistic. I understand completely what you mean about not daring to be happy, you feel like you're tempting fate. I feel exactly the same.  If you're like me your anxiety over recurrence has become such a powerful force, such an evil creature that it's almost become an actual character, a personality, alive somehow. Something that strong won't easily be silenced so whenever you dare to be happy it raises it's ugly head and warns you its' still there, tells you not to be too happy.  With the help of some CBT (on the NHS) I'm trying to accept good days and if anxiety pops up acknowledge it's presence but say, " I know you, I know your game. I've seen you but I'm far too busy dancing/drinking cocktails/ enjoying the view so feck off!" Does any of that make the slightest sense? Caz x
Posts.Title: Anyone Feel Like This

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Sal and others. Feel a bit more on it this morning.  Xx
Posts.Title: New year, feeling blue

Posts.Content: Hi M I'm not sure how useful I'll be cos I had my diep as immediate reconstruction, mastectomy done July 11th this year. 3 months post op my movement is pretty much normal, the boob looks pretty good and I think I made the right choice. My surgery was just 6 weeks after end of chemo and 8 weeks before radiotherapy which I finished a fortnight ago. Obviously the boob is numb and as I had lymph clearance, the armpit too but in addition a large area of my tummy is numb. The scar is ok though, quite proud of it actually and a flat tummy is nice.  Please message if you've any specific questions. Carolyn.
Posts.Title: Worrying about diep flap surgery in january help please?

Posts.Content: Sat crying as everyone in the next room parties with the music cranked up. I'm normally the life and soul but having finished active treatment in October for stage 3c cancer I find myself terrified of what 2018 might bring. Try to keep my posts positive but feeling very miserable. Xx
Posts.Title: New year, feeling blue

Posts.Content: Cheers girls, can someone remind me of the name of the numbing cream?
Posts.Title: Am i a wuss to fear Zoladex?

Posts.Content: Right, I'll start by answering my own question..   I am not a wuss! I've had 6 x chemo Mastectomy with immediate reconstruction  15 X radiotherapy  And not cried out in pain once. But today, first Zoladex implant (That thing is not just an injection) and it bloody hurt! Has anyone else had that? Is it because of my diep tummy? Should I have been offered some sort of anaesthetic? I was going back to Slimming World tonight to shift the last of the chemo (cake) weight... but now I'm gonna eat chocolate, I deserve it.
Posts.Title: Am i a wuss to fear Zoladex?

Posts.Content: Thanks Sal.  Xx
Posts.Title: Am i a wuss to fear Zoladex?

Posts.Content: So, here's the thing...2 months since diagnosis, 3 chemos done, bald as a coot and I Still don't believe I've got cancer. I can list what it is, left breast 9cm tumour, at its widest point, grade 2, stage 3, ER+, Her- but I don't believe it. I can feel it, i found the feckin lump, too young at 46 for screening, but I don't believe it. Is it just me? My point is, before surgery I feel I need slapping in the face with reality. Perhaps, this is a downside of chemo first. What I'd really 'like' is to see an image of it. That's my question, has anyone ever seen any images of theirs? I know the MRI is thousands of images, but somewhere in our fat files is there a picture I could ask to see?  My oncologist rang last night to say an MRI i had done just after chemo 3 showed shrinkage and my lovely family and friends are all hugely excited by that. All I can think is, I'm having a mastectomy, what does the size of the tumour matter. But maybe if i could see pictures, I'd be able to see progress and start to believe it's actually there! Batfink.
Posts.Title: Tumour shrinkage and scan images

Posts.Content: They never seem to be in a room with a working computer... But will definitely be asking.
Posts.Title: Tumour shrinkage and scan images

Posts.Content: Thanks Karen. I've been ok with needles myself, until today! Hugs back at ya. Xx
Posts.Title: Am i a wuss to fear Zoladex?

Posts.Content: Very, very normal to dip when active treatment ends. I'e found CBT and a Moving Forward course are helping. Xx
Posts.Title: Weird feelings

Posts.Content: It's my birthday Today, 47. On diagnosis with stage 3c back in january I thought my gravestone would read 'aged 46' (drama queen, me?). So, I wondered how many birthdays you'd all had that you didn't expect to reach? Now I'm off to eat cake and make merry.
Posts.Title: A birthday i thought I'd never reach...

Posts.Content: Happy birthday Linn, you young slip of a thing! Xxx
Posts.Title: A birthday i thought I'd never reach...

Posts.Content: Nothing massively inspiring to add ladies, but I just wanted to say.... Firstly my chemo was EC not FEC and I was really pissed off cos it sounds like a Yorkshire farmer not a drunk Irish priest! Second, I didn't cold cap, figured I had enough to endure, and 4 months post chemo my hair is coming back slightly greyer (I'm 46) but in better condition than it's ever been! Onwards and upwards lasses, be kind to yourselves.
Posts.Title: FEC it is then

Posts.Content: Hi all I've been having real problems with zoladex and have been offered an alternative that is a liquid rather than a pellet. I want to research it a bit, but like the fool that I am didn't ask what it was called . Duh. Research would suggest Lupron. Does anyone know?
Posts.Title: Like zoladex but not zoladex

Posts.Content: I don't think i had any particular physical symptoms but i did have some weird mental ones. I've always been a really positive person, annoyingly so, but all last year i kept thinking, "my life is too perfect, i don't deserve it, surely I'm due a big trauma". I also gave up several commitments that I've had and enjoyed for years and i could only explain it by saying i needed to be with my family, i have 2 young lads. I don't believe in fate, that I somehow brought the cancer on, but rather that at some level I knew that this year would be my 'having breast cancer' year.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi Josephine I am on daily Ibandronic acid, started it in October. Everyone is different of course and I am on other drugs so hard to know which causes the side effects, but I've had no indigestion problems. It's a damn nuisance cos you have to take it an hour before any food or drink but a warm water is part of my morning routine now and almost as good as a cup of tea (not really but trying to make myself believe it). I also take Exesmestane and have been on Zoladex implants but am having my ovaries out on Friday. Such fun! Xx
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Dearest ovaries I'm writing because I feel I owe you some sort of explanation. As you lie there in your Bert bag (whatever that is), waiting to be examined, you must be wondering what you did to be ousted along with Mrs and Mrs Fallopian. Our relationship began so well. You were there when I was born already stuffed with all the eggs I'd ever need. True, it took you a while to get the hang of releasing them and you never did learn the art of punctuality but I forgave you that when 14 years ago you released your first perfect ovum. It contained half of everything needed to make the cutest baby, most loving toddler and all round funny teenager. You triumphed again four years later. Thank you so much for another perfect little man. Eggs weren't your only job of course, you are my primary source of Oestrogen and Progesterone. I was very grateful for this in my teens when they gave me a waist and boobs, less keen on the hairy armpits though if we're being frank. I don't blame you , how were you to know, that years later one of those boobs would go rogue, tits-up if you prefer, and start to harbour a great secret. Not content with allowing cells to grow uncontrolled it looked to you for help! Damn cheek, actually using my own hormones to aid it in it's evil multiplication. So you see, you just had to go. I'm sure it wasn't a complete shock, those hideous Zoladex implants must have been a bit of a clue that you were no longer welcome! So, as we part ways, I just want you to know that I'm grateful for all you have given me and that you at least, stayed cancer free, but I refuse to shed any more tears over your loss. I do hope you understand. Love from what's left of Carolyn. Ps should you bump into my lymph nodes please thank them for doing their very best to help out, hopefully they've saved me.
Posts.Title: Ovaries removed yesterday.

Posts.Content: Thanks Tigger Hope you're doing ok yourself. I'm lying in bed with the aroma of pulled pork wafting upstairs feeling grateful that I married a man who can cook! Xxx
Posts.Title: Ovaries removed yesterday.

Posts.Content: Definitely milking it, about to have tea in bed. Xx
Posts.Title: Ovaries removed yesterday.
